name: Transcriptional profiling of right extensor digitorum longus muscle from mice flown on the RR-23 mission
purpose: To understand the effects of spaceflight on the eyes, specifically on the structure and function of arteries, veins, and lymphatic vessels critical to maintaining vision.

groups.treatment: Mice were flown to the ISS for 38 days and maintained in microgravity conditions.
groups.results: Right extensor digitorum longus muscle samples were collected and sequenced.

groups.treatment: Mice were housed in identical ground-based habitats under normal gravity.
groups.results: Right extensor digitorum longus muscle samples were collected and sequenced.

groups.treatment: Mice were housed in standard vivarium cages under normal gravity.
groups.results: Right extensor digitorum longus muscle samples were collected and sequenced.

pre_launch_events.event: Mice were prepared for spaceflight and housed in the Rodent Transporter aboard the SpaceX-21 mission.
Mice were transferred to two Rodent Habitats upon arrival at the ISS.

post_return_events.event: Mice returned to Earth via Live Animal Return (LAR) after splashdown in the Atlantic Ocean and were transported to Kennedy Space Center.
Mice were euthanized and tissue samples were collected at Texas A&M University.
Samples were processed, and RNA sequencing was performed on right extensor digitorum longus muscles.

osdr_experiments.description: RNA sequencing of rodent muscle samples from prior spaceflight missions using a similar setup.

same_subject_experiments.description: Study focusing on ocular vascular hydrodynamics in spaceflight with tissue samples from the same subjects.
